thread.title: Poor health costing the North £13bn, new report finds

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Poor health costing the North £13bn, new report finds
text:

More than £13bn could be added to the economy of the North by tackling the health inequalities that exist with other parts of the country, a new report says.
The Health for Wealth: report, which will be launched in Newcastle today , says that increasing the NHS budget in the North East could health close the productivity gap which currently sees people in the region producing £4 an hour less than other parts of the country.
Action to reduce poor health would narrow the employment gap with the rest of England and improve productivity to such an extend that the region would add an additional £13.2bn to the economy. Prof Clare Bambra, Newcastle University (Image: publicity handout from Newcastle University)
The report - which has been commissioned by Northern Health Science Alliance and compiled by six universities - points out that 60% of health research is carried in the ‘golden triangle’ of London, Cambridge and Oxford.
Lead author Professor Clare Bambra, from Newcastle University, said: “This report demonstrates the connection between poor productivity and higher rates of ill health in the North. If you improve health in the North you will improve its productivity – potentially benefiting the whole of the UK’s economy. Read More Newcastle University outlines vision to become world leader
“For the Northern Powerhouse to reach its full potential there needs to be increased investment in place-based public health in local authorities. There needs to be increased NHS funding in the North, spent on prevention services and health science research.
“Work needs to be done to improve labour market participation and job retention among people with a health condition in the region. Poorer health in the North affects the entire country’s economy, a healthier Northern Powerhouse will mean a healthier UK economy.”
The report found that people in the North suffering a bout of ill health are 39% more likely to lose their job compared to their counterparts in the rest of England. If they return to work, their wages are 66% lower than people in the same situation elsewhere in the country. Dr Hakim Yadi, chief executive of the Northern Health Science Alliance
But if the region could reduce rates of ill health by 1.2% and mortality rates by 0.7%, that would reduce the gap in gross value added (GVA) per-head between the North and the rest of England by 10%.
The report will be launched today at an event in Newcastle with Dame Jackie Daniel, chief executive Newcastle Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes, Tees Valley mayor Ben Houchen and Dr Hakim Yadi, CEO of the Northern Health Science Alliance.
It recommends improving health in the North by increasing investment in public health and upping NHS funding in the region, particularly looking at prevention services and health research.
The report also calls for businesses to support “job retention and health promotion interventions”. Read More Breakthrough cancer test developed in Newcastle gets financial backing
Dr Yadi said: “We’re missing out on £13.2bn in the North’s economy by not being smart with investment in health.
“Post-Brexit we need to build a stronger, healthier UK economy and the North of England is a key part of this. By improving health we can also make a direct impact on productivity and that is something no government should ignore.” Like us on Facebook
